No small amount of criticism has been passed upon the grouping together in one department of a legal system of the topics which are comprised under the ius quod ad res pertinet, and which, we may truly say, would not be coordinated upon any other principle of classirication. The most solid objection is the inclusion of the law of Inheritance and that of obligations in the same division with that of property and other real rights. The place of the first is due to its character as one of the modes of universal succession, among which it ranks with adrogation‚ bonorum addictio libertatis causa, and (iu Gaius) conventio in manum, hereditatis in iure cessio, and venditio bonorum. Through this false idea of proportion the importance of T estamenmry and intestate succession, as an independent branch of law, is altogether obscured: moreover, as Savigny has remarked, these modes ‘quibus res per universitatem adquiruntur' are ex· clusively regarded as titles to rights, whereas they are equally sources of obligations. Accordingly, the German jurists‚ in their systematic treatises on Roman law, bere abandon the Roman classification, and make Inheritance one of their main divisione, instead of subordinating it to that between titles to res singulae, and titles to universitates.
